replies.msg:
The Lordstown Motors chart is similar, as is the chart for many other SPAC mergers. The hedge funds that provide the finance for the SPAC IPO often sell shares during this period, recouping their investment, freeing up funds for another deal, and retaining the warrants to participate in any further upside. It is a risk-free strategy for them.

The bubble in EV stocks seems to be deflating with Tesla, Nio (NIO) and Xpeng (XPEV) all pulling back from their year-to-date highs. There are a lot of small companies trying to enter the EV space, and with the major auto companies all moving into the same space, it is hard to see how the inflated valuations can be justified.

If you are looking at Lucid as a long-term investment, there will probably be a more attractive entry point, either between now and the closure of the merger or after the expiry of the lock-downs. It is an interesting company, but not at the price that investors are paying right now.

https://seekingalpha.com/amp/article/4408013-churchill-lucid-wait-for-better-entry-point
